MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


2.34 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [21st November, 1961] to Question [20th November, 1961],

    "That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya."-(The Minister for Labour-Inche Ahmad bin Ibrahim).

    Which Amendment was,

    'To leave out from "a" in the second last line to the end and insert:

    "genuine merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth state and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal Citizens on Merger Day".'-(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

2.35 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy): Mr Speaker, Sir, on Friday I was saying that the Barisan Sosialis were first asking for full and complete merger on the basis of Penang and Malacca. But now, when they are told

Column: 719

that complete merger on that basis will not enable all Singapore citizens to become Federal citizens, they do not mention any more of Penang and Malacca but ask for automatic conversion of all Singapore citizens into Federal citizens.

    Our Prime Minister has already said that it is unreasonable for us to put up such demands. I would like to show an example to the Barisan Sosialis how it is unreasonable. Suppose two brothers came from a Commonwealth country to Malaya in 1955. One brother settled in Singapore. The other brother settled in Johore Bahru. In 1957, Singapore citizenship laws came into being. In 1957 the brother in Singapore, who had already lived in Singapore for two years, became a Singapore citizen. Now, on the Barisan type of merger, he would become a Federal citizen on the attainment of merger. But the brother who came to Johore Bahru at the same time as his counterpart came to Singapore, and who had lived the same number of years would not be able to become a Federal citizen. But the brother in Singapore would become a Federal citizen. Is this reasonable or unreasonable? Let the Barisan Sosialis say it. Is it not unreasonable to grant citizenship to one man and refuse it to the other when both have the same qualifications?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it was alleged by the Members for Queenstown and Changi that after merger on the terms set out in the White Paper, Singapore citizens will become second-class citizens. In what way will Singapore citizens become second-class citizens? It is no use one speaker after another repeating this falsehood without showing how the Singapore citizen will become a second-class citizen.

    The only reason the Barisan Sosialis have put forward is that Singapore citizens cannot vote or stand for election to the Federal Parliament in the Federation. Federal citizens also cannot vote or stand for election to the Federal Parliament in Singapore. Why then is one citizen inferior to the other? If they say the Singapore citizen is second-class, it can also be said that the Federal citizen is also second-class.

Column: 720



    I know that the Minister for Culture has dealt with this point, but even after the Minister's speech, the Barisan Sosialis keep on repeating the unfounded allegation that Singapore citizens are second-class, so that they hope that if this is repeated again and again by all their 13 Members and published in the Press, people who read it can be misled into believing what they say is true.

    The Member for Changi said citizenship was a fundamental right of the people. Who says it is not? He says after the merger proposed in the White Paper this right will be taken away. How will it be taken away?

    The Member for Queenstown also said on 21st November (Straits Times, 22nd November), "It means, in the first place, that if a Singapore citizen goes to the Federation after the P.A.P. phoney merger, he will become disenfranchised and will not be allowed to vote or to stand for election in the Federation." What a deliberate falsehood. Even now, if a Singapore citizen goes to the Federation, he will not lose his Singapore citizenship. Is it anywhere stated that he will lose his Singapore citizenship right, if he goes to the Federation after merger? All these deliberate falsehoods are uttered to mislead the people and mobilise agitation for merger. It is true that if a Singapore citizen goes to the Federation, he will not be allowed to vote or stand for election in the Federation, but he will never lose his Singapore citizenship rights. He will not become disenfranchised. If a Singapore citizen wants to become a Federal citizen, that is a different matter. In the same way, if a Federal citizen comes to Singapore and wants to become a Singapore citizen, he has to apply for it.

    The Barisan Sosialis' main object is nothing but to oppose merger. That is why they allege all these falsehoods, so that they can get the people to believe that the people are losing their rights. You will see, Mr Speaker, Sir, from what I am going to state, how insincere, vicious and mischievous they are in their utterances.

    The Member for Changi on Friday said that by the White Paper proposals, Singapore citizens, if they want to stand for election, have to have a knowledge

Column: 721

of English or Malay, after merger, or else they cannot stand for election. This is true only to the extent of Federal Parliament elections. But the Member went on to say that now, knowledge of Chinese is sufficient, but after the P.A.P. merger, people who know only Chinese cannot stand for election to the Federal Parliament. He said so, Sir. It is not reported in the Straits Times, but it might have been reported in the Chinese Press. What is the real intention of this allegation? The intention is to say that the P.A.P. is taking away the right of the Chinese-educated to stand for election. Now, let the Barisan Sosialis tell us, according to the complete merger they are asking for, can a man who does not know English or Malay stand for Federal election? At least, with autonomy in Singapore's domestic affairs, according to the White Paper proposals, there will be a multilingual Singapore Legislature. If it is a complete merger, there will not be a multilingual Singapore Legislature. They will have only a bilingual Legislative Assembly or Council as in Penang.

    The Member for Queenstown on 20th November, talked about what citizenship means and what are the benefits the citizen will get, besides the right to vote. It is also true that only citizens can get permanent employment in Government; only citizens can be given land for resettlement; only citizens can apply for Housing and Development Board flats; only citizens can get legal aid and public assistance; only citizens are given passports; and only citizens cannot be banished. He also said that only children of citizens are given preference to others in schools and in getting scholarships. Thus, he was telling this House of the importance of citizenship. Then he went on to say, "If merger is to have any meaning, then Singapore citizens must become Federal citizens. Only then will Singapore citizens have the opportunity of sharing all these benefits." He then suggested that if a Singapore citizen does not become a Federal citizen, he will lose all his rights. How will a Singapore citizen Jose all his rights if he does not become a Federal citizen? He never said how.

Column: 722



    Will Singapore citizens be refused employment in the Government service? Will they be refused public assistance and legal aid'? Will they not get Housing and Development flats? He did not quote one single instance of how Singapore citizens will lose any of these rights if they do not become Federal citizens after merger. He calls the proposals in the White Paper a betrayal, treachery, sell-out, phoney merger, and so on. Even the Member for Anson - though he supports the amendment for various reasons - admits that the proposals are the best in the circumstances. He even complimented, Sir. The only thing he said is that it is not a merger. But the Barisan Sosialis say that all this is a sell-out and they call for general elections. They ask us to resign. I would like to tell the Members of the Barisan Sosialis once again that they were elected to this Assembly on the P.A.P. ticket and that they had pledged to resign if they were ever expelled. Let them honour their word. They cannot just say that they represent the public and that the people are with them. If they really want to know whether the public are with them in their demand for a complete merger with autonomy in domestic affairs, such as education, social welfare, labour, trade, and so on, they should resign their seats and prove their support.

    I remember the Member for Changi said the other day - though it was not reported in the Straits Times - that they were elected not because of the P.A.P. leaders but because of the socialists in the Barisan Sosialis who were then in the P.A.P. Except for the Members for Thomson, Havelock, Toa Payoh and Moulmein, none of the present Barisan Sosialis Assemblymen were ever heard of before 1959. At that time, the present important non-Assemblymen leaders of the Barisan Sosialis were in prison. I stress that they were elected on the record of the P.A.P. under the present leadership and not on any other thing. Those who do not honour their word stabbed us in the back at the time of a crucial by-election and helped an opponent to win his election. It is too much to expect of them, Sir!

Column: 723



    The Barisan Sosialis talk of complete merger in this House. But what do they do outside? Their rank and file and their agents go to the ordinary people and propagate that if there is merger the people of Singapore will have to wear sarongs, songkoks, accept Islam as their religion, Malay as their only language, and so on, thus frightening the people. Even this morning, Sir, their people were going around in front of my house and putting up posters all over the place agitating for this 4:2 education system. These are the people who say that the people will accept the Federation's education policy. Is this the way they are going to persuade the people of Singapore to accept the Federation's education and labour policies in a complete merger?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): On a point of order. What is the basis for these allegations?

    Mr Speaker: It is not a point of order. That is a point of argument.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Read the Standing Orders.

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Ramaswamy: On 23rd November, the Member for Changi said:

    'In the State today, the masses were openly decrying the P.A.P. Government. In coffee-shops and hawker-stalls, the people were highly critical of the Government.'

It is not true. It is these Barisan Sosialis men who talk of one thing in this House and then go to the people to instigate them with all sorts of lies against merger.

    An hon. Member: The Straits Times!

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not know whether the word "lies" was used with reference to Members of this Assembly. If it was, then the hon. Member must withdraw the word.

    Mr Ramaswamy: I was mentioning the agents who work. It is not true that the people do not like merger as proposed in the White Paper. It is these Barisan Sosialis men who tell the people falsehoods about citizenship, education and labour, and try to confuse them and arouse their emotional feelings. Even in

Column: 724

this House the Member for Queenstown (the Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis) asked a lot of questions. What is the purpose of asking these questions when they know full well that the people will be better off and they will have nothing to complain about in a merger as proposed in the White Paper than in a merger as proposed by the Barisan Sosialis'? Their purpose is to create an impression in the minds of the people that they will suffer under the White Paper proposals. When the Minister for Culture was saying the same thing, the Member for Havelock asked the Minister to answer them as though the answers will show the people that they will suffer. T shall answer the questions, Sir. Let them see in what way the people will suffer because of the merger. The questions are in the Straits Times of 22nd November in a speech made by the Member for Queenstown.

    Question No. 1 reads: "What would the civil servants gain with merger'? Would they get more opportunities for promotion in a wider service under the same terms existing or under better terms? Would promotion be accelerated?" If there is complete merger - as proposed by the Barisan Sosialis -recruitment into the civil service will be in the 4: 1 ratio as in the Federation. But according to the White Paper proposals, Singapore citizens will have equal rights and opportunities for recruitment. The Member for Anson came to their rescue and tried to tell us that this will not affect us as this ratio relates only to the Federal service and not to the State service. The Deputy Prime Minister has cleared this point by pointing out the departments that will be left in the State service after merger. Except for the Land Office, no other big department will be in the State service. Therefore, in a complete merger, the majority of the civil servants will be affected.

    Questions 2 and 3 read: "Would bus companies be allowed to operate freely on new routes in the Federation? Would they be treated equally as others? Would contractors get the same opportunities for business in the Federation as in Singapore?" The same argument as for

Column: 725

the civil service will apply to these questions also. Bus companies in Singapore will have their present rights in Singapore in the White Paper proposals. But in a complete merger, the same practice in the Federation will have to apply to Singapore bus companies also. Which will benefit them more - complete merger or merger with autonomy in domestic affairs? Contractors who are Singapore citizens will have preference over the Federal citizens in getting jobs in Singapore. Federal citizens will get preference in the Federation. In a complete merger, certain type of contracts, even in Singapore, will have to be given to Malays. Let the Barisan Sosialis remember that there is a policy in the Federation by which certain types of contracts are to he given only to the indigenous people of Malaya.

    Question No. 4 reads: "Would Singapore citizens be able to apply for jobs in the Federation after merger? Would they be discriminated against because they are not Federal citizens?" Even now Singapore citizens are able to apply for jobs in both territories. Federal citizens are also able to apply for jobs in both territories. Preference may be given to Singapore citizens in the Singapore Government and to Federal citizens in the Federal Government. After merger, arrangements will be made to all Federal nationals to be given preference in both territories.

    Question No. 5 reads: "Would the products of Singapore schools and universities he allowed to apply for jobs in the Federation?" Here at the present moment, there is no denial of this right. I do not know why the Member for Queenstown thinks otherwise.

    Questions 6 and 7 ask whether all Singapore citizens would accept the security risk of moving about freely in the Federation. Except for the people who will try to undermine the democratic Government in the Federation, all people will be allowed to move about freely.

    Question No. 8 reads: "Would students from Singapore schools and universities - particularly Nanyang University - have the right to travel freely in

Column: 726

the Federation?" If there is to be a complete merger without autonomy in domestic affairs, there may not be Nanyang University and no such question would then arise.

    Questions 9, 10, 11 and 12 - all the same reply, Sir. When there is autonomy in labour with different labour laws in the Federation and Singapore, it is only natural that there will be separate bodies of trade unions. But if there is to be a complete merger, are the Barisan Sosialis prepared to accept the same labour laws as in the Federation? Let them say clearly that they will accept the Federation's education policy, the Rahman Talib Report on Education, and so on. The Barisan Sosialis also know, of course, that non-Federal citizens cannot hold office in any territory in the Federation. Non-Federal citizens will not be made leaders as in Singapore after merger, if it is going to be a complete merger.

    About businessmen, they ask, "Will they have equal opportunities?" Even now businessmen are enjoying equal opportunities. There is no inequality in the rights of businessmen in Singapore and the Federation. What make the Barisan Sosialis think that there will be a difference after merger? I do not know.

    As I said earlier, Mr Speaker, these questions are put only to confuse the people and leave an impression that the people will lose their rights after merger, thus getting them to oppose merger.

    The Member for Changi has been repeating the same thing - unequal rights. Where are the unequal rights? In what way are the citizens of the two territories unequal? Let them point out one instance. And without any substantiation, all this propaganda will only mean that they are opposed to merger. And they are putting up these unreasonable demands and obstacles only to sabotage merger.

    Before ending my speech, Mr Speaker, Sir, let me deal with certain points raised by the Member for Anson who unfortunately is not in this Chamber at the moment. On the question of

Column: 727

equal treatment for all the four streams of education, he admitted that there was a radical divergence in the Federation education policy, and if the people of Singapore did not wish to perpetuate this difference, a Federal Act could easily provide for the maintenance and administration of the existing education policy in Singapore. What does this mean? This means that he wants a different education policy for Singapore. Instead of mingling words and misleading the people, can he not acknowledge that this is what the P.A.P. wants by retaining autonomy in education? He said that a Federal Act could easily be passed. Of course, he knows - he is a renowned lawyer - as well as we do, that to do this, there should be a majority of Members of Parliament to agree to any enactment of any Act or law. Suppose after merger we do not get a majority to agree to pass this Act. What will happen? Is the Member for Anson prepared to forget about it? He personally may. Will the people of Singapore agree to this? That is why we ask for autonomy in education beforehand.

    And for labour also, the Member for Anson said, "Even if Singapore had full labour legislation and policies, there was nothing to prevent the Federal Government authorising the State Government here to exercise responsibility in this field." What does this also mean? Does this not mean autonomy in labour? He says, "Let us have complete merger", and then says, "Let the State Government be authorised to exercise responsibility in this field." Why has he got to mislead the people in this way instead of accepting autonomy on labour, education, and so on? He might as well say, "Let us have complete merger, and then pass Acts in the Federal Parliament providing the Singapore Government to exercise responsibility in internal security as well." Why stop at that? Pass Acts in the Federal Parliament to transfer full responsibility for defence and external affairs of the whole of the Federation of Malaya and Singapore to the Singapore Legislature so that the Barisan Sosialis can change the foreign policy of Malaya to suit them. Then the Member for Anson and

Column: 728

his friends in the Barisan Sosialis will be very, very happy.

    Lastly, the Member for Anson wanted to know for a fact the number of Communists in Singapore and whether there are really so many Communists in this State. I would like to remind him of his days in the year 1956 when he was Chief Minister of Singapore, and when there were the Hock Lee riots, and he introduced the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance to replace the Emergency Regulations. If there were no Communists in this State, why did he introduce the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance? Has he forgotten the Hock Lee riots? Who instigated those riots? Who were behind them? Are the very same people not living amongst us, or have they disappeared? This is one instance, Sir.

    Another instance. After the Tanjong Pagar and Cairnhill by-elections in 1957, the present Member for Anson said that he had retired from politics. And at the end of 1957 the Workers' Party was formed with Mr Chang Yuen Thong as Vice-Chairman. The Workers' Party won three out of four seats in the City council, and with an overwhelming majority. Then, as we were told by the Prime Minister in one of his talks over Radio Singapore, Chang Yuen Thong resigned from the Workers' Party and the City Council. When Chang Yuen Thong resigned, there was a by-election in Kallang. The Workers' Party candidate who contested. the Kallang by-election got only 300 odd votes.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Can the Member help the Chair by indicating how this is relevant to the motion? Is it relevant to Communism?

    Mr Ramaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson asked the other day whether there were Communists or whether there were too many Communists in Singapore.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have asked the Member to explain.

    Mr Ramaswamy: I am only trying to explain that there are Communists in Singapore at the moment.

Column: 729



    Mr Speaker: Yes, I understand that. But have these by-elections anything to do with Communism? I really do not understand that.

    Mr Ramaswamy: I am going to prove that. Sir. They contested the elections and won an overwhelming majority in December 1957.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may. Mr Speaker, is it not a point of order where the Member misrepresents completely a statement made in this House? If it is not, then it is not a point of order.

    Mr Speaker: It is not a point of order. But, of course, the hon. Member will have his opportunity if he has been misunderstood or misrepresented. There is a Standing Order which enables the Member or any Member to correct the misunderstanding, and that is Standing Order 43, paragraph (4) :

    'A Member who has spoken to a question may again he heard to offer an explanation of some material part of his speech which has been misunderstood; hut he shall not introduce any new matter.'

If the hon. Member feels he has been misunderstood in a material part of his speech. then he may speak again after the Parliamentary Secretary has ceased to speak.

    Mr Ramaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1958 Chang Yuen Thong resigned from the Workers' Party, as told to us by the Prime Minister in one of his talks. He met the "Plen", and the Plen said he would instruct Chang Yuen Thong to resign from the Workers' Party and the City Council. And it was carried out. I am just saying these things to prove that the events related to us by the Prime Minister are all true, and that there are Communists in Singapore.

    The Workers' Party candidate who contested the Kallang by-election got only 300-odd votes.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Is the inference, therefore, that those who did not vote for the Workers' Party were Communists? Is that what the hon. Member is indicating?

Column: 730



    Mr Ramaswamy: What I am saying is that in 1957 Communists infiltrated into the Workers' Party and they helped the Workers' Party to win in so many elections with an overwhelming majority. In 1958 they deserted the Workers' Party and that was why the candidate who stood for election got only 300-odd votes. That is what I am trying to explain, Sir. Where had all the support for the Workers' Party in 1957 gone, 111 1958? How does the Member for Anson explain the sudden rise and fall of the Workers' Party in those years? If he does not agree with the Prime Minister's version of the events which led to the resignation of Chang Yuen Thong, how does he explain it? Do not all these facts prove the existence of Communists in this State?

    Mr David Marshall: Who said this?

    Mr Ramaswamy: Lastly, may I end this speech by asking the Barisan Sosialis on the Opposition Benches to take note of all these events? Think of the future of Singapore. If they want a real unification of Singapore and the Federation, do not call the people of the Federation of Malaya Manchurians and so on.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan (Changi) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Point of explanation, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way. He has not given way.

    Mr Ramaswamy: Take the White Paper proposals as a first step towards the reunification of both territories. Therefore, I say to this House that we should reject this amendment, Sir.

    Mr David Marshall: A personal explanation, Sir, under the Standing Order you have referred to.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the hon. Member is once again late. Under Standing Order 10, paragraph (1) (n), personal explanations, if any, must be made before Public business, and we are now on Public business.

Column: 731



3.13 p.m.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, despite the fact that we have been debating this vital issue of merger for more than five days, we have people who are as confused as ever in the maze of arguments, counter arguments, and counter-counter arguments, as what we have the counterpart in power politics, the development of missiles, anti-missiles, and anti-anti-missiles. In my speech, therefore, as far as I can, I am avoiding reference to the legal technicalities of the Federation Constitution, or making quotations from it. I will also try to refrain from delving into the details of the White Paper at this stage.

    Since there has been so much confusion on this subject of merger, I think it is important that we should discuss the issue dispassionately and without personal rancour or bitterness. Electioneering techniques or mass meeting techniques will not help us to clarify the issue. There have been doubts and confusion on this issue. Sir, the confusion has been partly due to the introduction of personalities into this subject and the petty squabbles during the past few months. All along we have remained silent because we do not want to be involved in these petty squabbles. The doubts have been due mainly to the way the Government brought forward its so-called merger proposals.

    You will remember, Sir, that the Government rejected merger talks with the Federation when they were requested to do so in one of the 16 Hong Lim Resolutions. As far as I can see, it was only after the Hong Lim by-election that the Government commenced constitutional talks with the Federation.

    Sir, there are broadly three types of views on merger. Firstly, there are those who support the principle of complete merger. Secondly, there are those who accept the proposal of the Government for - for want of a better name - I will call a tiga suku merger. In the third group are those who are opposed to any form of association with the Federation. We can now ignore this third

Column: 732

group, because, for obvious reasons, nobody in this third group dares to come out openly to say that he is opposed to merger.

    Sir, there have been many interpretations of what is complete merger. What is complete merger? If we have complete merger, if Singapore accepts complete merger, we would he like the State of Johore. All Singapore citizens could become Federal citizens. We could vote about 21 candidates, as the Minister for Health and Law has calculated - and this we will not argue or dispute at the moment - to the Federal Parliament. This figure of 21 can be worked out later whether it is correct or not. Now, if there is complete merger, we would have, at the same time, a Singapore State Government, like the present Johore State Government, with a Chief Minister and an Executive Council. What are the powers of the present State Government in Johore? They have jurisdiction over the following subjects:

    (1) Muslim law;

    (2) Land matters;
